tn.text: Yahweh speaks to Ezekiel about the origins of the people of Israel.
"Yahweh spoke his word." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:01:01|1:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Both of these speak of when the city of Jerusalem was founded. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: father was an Amorite, and your mother was a Hittite
tn.text: Both of these nations developed the city of Jerusalem before the people of Israel existed. AT: "you were founded by the Amorites and the Hittites"
Yahweh compares Jerusalem to an unwanted baby.
"Nobody" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"people hated you"
Yahweh continues to speak about Jerusalem as an unwanted baby who grows into a beautiful woman.
Yahweh is walking near the newborn baby.
body hair

tn.ref: you became the jewel of jewels
tn.text: Here the woman, who represents Jerusalem, is spoken of as if she had become the finest of all jewels, that is, as if she had become the most beautiful of all women. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you became the jewel of jewels
tn.text: Some modern versions translate "You became old enough to wear jewels."
These two words mean the same thing and emphasize that she was completely naked. AT: "completely naked" (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Yahweh continues to speak about Jerusalem and the people of Israel as a young woman.
This is to say that Yahweh has walked by the young woman.

tn.ref: the time of love came for you
tn.text: This is to say that Yahweh sees the young woman is old enough to be married.
Yahweh continues to speak about Jerusalem and the people of Israel as a young woman.
different colored pieces of cloth sewn together to form a design.
"I added decoration to you"
Yahweh continues to speak about Jerusalem and the people of Israel as a young woman.
"decorated"
being known and respected by a lot of people.
Yahweh continues to speak about Jerusalem and the people of Israel as his wife.

tn.ref: But you trusted in your own beauty
tn.text: "thought your own beauty could provide for your needs"
This compares the people of Israel worshiping idols with a woman who is paid to sleep with strangers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Moral or immoral actions and qualities are often spoken of in the Bible as if they were liquids. AT: "freely committed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The acts of prostitution were committed for those who passed by. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This Hebrew phrase is translated in many different ways by various modern versions.
Yahweh continues to speak about Jerusalem and the people of Israel as his unfaithful wife.
"statues of men" or "idols that look like men"

tn.ref: you did with them as a prostitute would do
tn.text: This is a polite way to say the young woman was sleeping with the male figures. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"placed as an offering in front of them"
Yahweh continues to speak about Jerusalem and the people of Israel as his unfaithful wife.
"gave birth to"

tn.ref: Are your acts of prostitution a small matter?
tn.text: AT: "you act like your acts of prostitution are not a serious sin." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
killed
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:16:06|16:7]].
Yahweh continues to speak to Jerusalem and the people of Israel.

tn.ref: this is the Lord Yahweh's declaration
tn.text: See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:05:11|5:11]].

tn.ref: you built yourself a vaulted chamber in every public place
tn.text: This phrase refers to building a place to worship idols.
Yahweh continues to speak about Jerusalem and the people of Israel as his unfaithful wife.
The beginning of the road is referred to as its head. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Yahweh continues to speak about Jerusalem and the people of Israel as his unfaithful wife.

tn.ref: I will strike you with my hand
tn.text: AT: "I will act against you with my power"
refers to stopping the supply of food.

tn.ref: I will hand your life over
tn.text: "I will give your life over"
Since Jerusalem has been referred to as a young woman, her enemy the Philistines are also referred to as young women.
Yahweh continues to speak about Jerusalem and the people of Israel as his unfaithful wife.

tn.ref: Why is your heart so weak?
tn.text: Here, the word "heart" refers to love and faithfulness. AT: "Why do you love me so little?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

The word "promiscuous" refers to a person who sleeps with many different people." The word "shameless" refers to a person who openly sins. Both of these words describe one thought. AT: "shamelessly promiscuous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hendiadys]])
See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:16:25|16:25]].
Yahweh continues to speak about Jerusalem and the people of Israel as his unfaithful wife.
This refers to accepting someone to sleep with them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Yahweh continues to speak about Jerusalem and the people of Israel as his unfaithful wife.
Actions having moral qualities are often spoken of as if they were liquid. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Some modern versions translate "poured your wealth out."

tn.ref: the blood of your children that you gave to your idols
tn.text: This refers to killing children as a sacrifice to idols.
alerts us to pay attention to what follows.
The word "nakedness" refers to a person being without clothing but also refers to seeing all of a person's faults. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Yahweh speaks about enemy soldiers as the lovers of Jerusalem

tn.ref: throw down your mound ... break down your high places
tn.text: These phrases are saying the same thing in different ways. This adds emphasis to the phrase. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:16:06|16:7]].
Yahweh speaks about enemy soldiers as the lovers of Jerusalem.

tn.ref: I will calm my fury against you; my anger will leave you
tn.text: The words "fury" and "anger" refer to the punishment that Yahweh inflicts because he is angry. The two phrases mean basically the same thing. AT: "I will stop punishing you because I will no longer be angry with you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Yahweh continues to speak about Jerusalem and the people of Israel as his unfaithful wife.
Yahweh is referring to earlier times. AT: "my kindness to you when you were young" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This alerts us to pay attention to what follows.

tn.ref: I myself will bring the punishment for your conduct on your own head
tn.text: AT: "I will punish you for how you have acted" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Yahweh continues to speak about Jerusalem and the people of Israel as his unfaithful wife.
"behold" alerts us to pay attention to what follows.
"who hated her husband"
Yahweh continues to refer to other nations as relatives of Jerusalem.
This word is used to mark a break in the teaching. Yahweh changes from his parable to command the people of Jerusalem.

tn.ref: do not walk in their ways or after their disgusting actions
tn.text: AT: "do not act like them or do the disgusting things that they do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Yahweh continues to refer to other nations as relatives of Jerusalem.

tn.ref: arrogant in her leisure, careless and unconcerned about anything
tn.text: Yahweh describes Sodom as a rich woman who has more than enough food and lives in security. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: She did not strengthen the hands of the poor and needy people
tn.text: The words "poor" and "needy" emphasize that these are people who cannot help themselves. AT: "She did not help the people who could not help themselves." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Yahweh continues to refer to other nations as relatives of Jerusalem.

tn.ref: you have shown that your sisters were better than you
tn.text: Yahweh uses this phrase three times to emphasize that the wicked cities of Samaria and Sodom were more righteous than Jerusalem.

tn.ref: Especially you, show your own shame
tn.text: Yahweh uses this phrase twice to emphasize how shamefully the people of Jerusalem have acted.
Yahweh continues to refer to other nations as relatives of Jerusalem.
"wealth"

tn.ref: you will show your shame; you will be humiliated
tn.text: Both of these phrases refer to Yahweh punishing the people of Jerusalem publicly. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Yahweh continues to refer to other nations as relatives of Jerusalem.

tn.ref: Sodom your sister was not even mentioned by your mouth
tn.text: AT: "You would not even say the name of Sodom your sister" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: you are an object of scorn
tn.text: refers to Jerusalem as something people talk badly about.
"hate"

tn.ref: You will show your shame and your disgusting actions
tn.text: "You will be humiliated and everyone will understand how sinful you have been"
Yahweh continues to speak to Jerusalem.

tn.ref: despised your oath by breaking the covenant
tn.text: AT: "decided your promise meant nothing so you can break a formal agreement"
Yahweh continues to refer to Jerusalem as an unfaithful wife and other nations as relatives of Jerusalem.
"remember"
"remember everything"

tn.ref: you will no longer open your mouth to speak
tn.text: AT: "you will no longer say anything"
